title: Granzyme B
text:
Granzyme B (GrB) is a <a href="serine%20protease">serine protease</a> most commonly found in the granules of <a href="natural%20killer%20cells">natural killer cells</a> (NK cells) and <a href="cytotoxic%20T%20cells">cytotoxic T cells</a>. It is secreted by these cells along with the pore forming protein <a href="perforin">perforin</a> to mediate <a href="apoptosis">apoptosis</a> in target cells.
Granzyme B has also more recently found to be produced by a wide range of non-cytotoxic cells ranging from <a href="basophil%20granulocyte">basophils</a> and <a href="mast%20cells">mast cells</a> to <a href="smooth%20muscle%20cells">smooth muscle cells</a>. The secondary functions of granzyme B are also numerous. Granzyme B has shown to be involved in inducing <a href="inflammation">inflammation</a> by stimulating <a href="cytokine">cytokine</a> release and is also involved in <a href="extracellular%20matrix">extracellular matrix</a> remodelling.
Elevated levels of granzyme B are also implicated in a number of <a href="autoimmune%20diseases">autoimmune diseases</a>, several skin diseases, and <a href="type%201%20diabetes">type 1 diabetes</a>.
Structure.
In humans, granzyme B is encoded by GZMB on chromosome 14q.11.2, which is 3.2kb long and consists of 5 <a href="exons">exons</a>. It is one of the most abundant granzymes of which there are 5 in humans and 10 in mice. Granzyme B is thought to have evolved from a <a href="granzyme%20H">granzyme H</a> related precursor and is more effective at lower concentrations than the other granzymes.
The enzyme is initially in an inactive precursor <a href="zymogen">zymogen</a> form, with an additional <a href="N-terminus">amino terminal</a> peptide sequence. This sequence can be cleaved by <a href="cathepsin%20C">cathepsin C</a>, removing 2 <a href="amino%20acids">amino acids</a>. <a href="Cathepsin%20H">Cathepsin H</a> has also been reported to activate granzyme B.
Granzyme B's structure consists of two 6 stranded <a href="%CE%B2%20sheets">β sheets</a> with 3 trans domain segments. In the granules of cytotoxic lymphocytes the enzyme can exist in two <a href="glycosylation">glycosylated</a> forms. The high mannose form weighs 32kDa and the complex form, 35kDa.
Granzyme B contains the <a href="catalytic%20triad">catalytic triad</a> <a href="histidine">histidine</a>-<a href="aspartic%20acid">aspartic acid</a>-<a href="serine">serine</a> in its <a href="active%20site">active site</a> and preferentially cleaves after an <a href="aspartic%20acid">aspartic acid</a> residue situated in the P1 position. The aspartic acid residue to be cleaved associates with an <a href="arginine">arginine</a> residue in the enzyme's binding pocket.
Granzyme B is active at a neutral <a href="pH">pH</a> and is therefore inactive in the acidic CTL granules. The enzyme is also rendered inactive when bound by <a href="SRGN">serglycin</a> in the granules to avoid apoptosis triggering inside the cytotoxic T cells themselves.
Delivery.
Granzyme B is released with perforin which inserts into a target cell's <a href="plasma%20membrane">plasma membrane</a> forming a <a href="Ion%20channel%20pore">pore</a>. Perforin has a radius of 5.5 nm and granzyme B has a <a href="stokes%20radius">stokes radius</a> of 2.5 nm and can therefore pass through the perforin pore into the target to be destroyed.
Alternatively, once released, granzyme B can bind to negatively charged <a href="heparan%20sulphate">heparan sulphate</a> containing receptors on a target cell and become <a href="endocytosis">endocytosed</a>. The <a href="Vesicle%20%28biology%20and%20chemistry%29">vesicles</a> that carry the enzyme inside then burst, exposing granzyme b to the <a href="cytoplasm">cytoplasm</a> and its <a href="substrate%20%28biochemistry%29">substrates</a>. <a href="Hsp70">Hsp-70</a> has also been linked to aiding granzyme B entry.
Granzyme B has also been proposed to enter a target by first exchanging its bound serglycin for negative <a href="phospholipids">phospholipids</a> in a target's plasma membrane. Entry then occurs by the less selective process of <a href="pinocytosis">absorptive pinocytosis</a>.
Granzyme B Mediated Apoptosis.
Once inside the target cell, granzyme B can cleave and activate initiator caspases <a href="caspase%208">8</a> and <a href="caspase%2010">10</a>, and executioner caspases <a href="caspase%203">3</a> and <a href="caspase%207">7</a> which trigger apoptosis. Caspase 7 is the most sensitive to granzyme B and caspases 3, 8, and 10 are only cleaved to intermediate fragments and need further cleavage for full activation.
Granzyme B can also cleave <a href="BH3%20interacting-domain%20death%20agonist">BID</a> leading to <a href="Bcl-2-associated%20X%20protein">BAX</a>/<a href="Bcl-2%20homologous%20antagonist%20killer">BAK</a> <a href="oligomerisation">oligomerisation</a> and <a href="cytochrome%20c">cytochrome c</a> release from the <a href="mitochondria">mitochondria</a>. Granzyme B can cleave <a href="Inhibitor%20of%20caspase-activated%20DNase">ICAD</a> leading to DNA fragmentation and the <a href="DNA%20laddering">laddering pattern</a> associated with apoptosis.
Granzyme B has a potential of over 300 substrates and can cleave <a href="Mcl-1">Mcl-1</a> in the <a href="outer%20mitochondrial%20membrane">outer mitochondrial membrane</a> relieving its inhibition of <a href="BCL2L11">Bim</a>. Bim stimulates BAX/BAK oligomerisation, mitochondrial membrane permeability and apoptosis. Granzyme B can also cleave <a href="HAX1">HAX1</a> (Hs-1 associated protein X-1) to facilitate mitochondria polarisation.
Granzyme B can also generate a cytotoxic level of mitochondrial <a href="reactive%20oxygen%20species">reactive oxygen species</a> (ROS) to mediate cell death. The caspase independent pathways of cell death are thought to have arisen to overcome <a href="viruses">viruses</a> that can inhibit caspases and prevent apoptosis.
Targets.
Nucleus.
Granzyme B has many substrates located in the <a href="Cell%20nucleus">nucleus</a>. Granzyme B can cleave <a href="Poly%20ADP%20ribose%20polymerase">PARP</a> (poly ADP ribose polymerase) and <a href="DNA-PKcs">DNA PK</a> (DNA protein kinase) to disrupt DNA repair and <a href="retrovirus">retroviral</a> DNA integration. Granzyme B can also cleave <a href="nucleophosmin">nucleophosmin</a>, <a href="topoisomerase%201">topoisomerase 1</a> and <a href="nucleolin">nucleolin</a> to prevent viral replication.
Granzyme B can cleave ICP4 from the <a href="Herpes%20simplex%20virus">HSV 1</a> virus which is an essential protein used for gene <a href="transactivation">transactivation</a> and <a href="nuclear%20mitotic%20apparatus%20protein%201">NUMA</a> (Nuclear mitotic apparatus protein) can be cleaved to prevent <a href="mitosis">mitosis</a>.
Granzyme B can also cleave <a href="DNA-binding%20protein">DBP</a> (DNA Binding Protein) into a 50 kDa fragment and then into an additional 60 kDa indirectly through the caspases it activates.
Extracellular Matrix.
Granzyme B can degrade many proteins in the extracellular matrix (ECM) including <a href="fibronectin">fibronectin</a>, <a href="vitronectin">vitronectin</a> and <a href="aggrecan">aggrecan</a>. Cleavage can cause cell death by <a href="anoikis">anoikis</a> and release alarmins from the ECM inducing inflammation. Fragments of fibronectin can attract <a href="neutrophils">neutrophils</a> and stimulate <a href="Matrix%20metalloproteinase">MMP</a> expression from <a href="chondrocytes">chondrocytes</a>. Basophils secrete granzyme B to degrade <a href="endothelium">endothelial</a> cell-cell contacts allowing <a href="extravasation">extravasation</a> to sites of inflammation.
Granzyme B can also induce inflammation by processing cytokines <a href="IL1A">IL-1α</a> and <a href="Interleukin%2018">IL18</a>. It can also trigger the release of <a href="Interleukin%206">IL6</a> and <a href="Interleukin%208">IL8</a> through activation of <a href="Coagulation%20factor%20II%20receptor">PAR1</a> (Protease activated receptor 1).
Cleavage of vitronectin occurs at the RGD <a href="integrin">integrin</a> binding site interrupting cell growth signalling pathways. Cleavage of <a href="laminin">laminin</a> and fibronectin disrupts <a href="dermoepidermal%20junction">dermal-epidermal junction</a> attachment and cross talk while decorin destruction by granzyme B causes <a href="collagen">collagen</a> disorganisation, skin thinning and aging. <a href="Keratinocytes">Keratinocytes</a> can express granzyme B after exposure to <a href="ultraviolet">UVA</a> and <a href="ultraviolet">UVB</a> which is linked to <a href="photoaging">photoaging</a> of the skin.
Granzyme B can also impair wound healing. Cleavage of the <a href="von%20Willebrand%20factor">von Willebrand factor</a> inhibits <a href="platelet">platelet</a> aggregation and of <a href="plasminogen">plasminogen</a> produces an <a href="angiostatin">angiostatin</a> fragment preventing <a href="angiogenesis">angiogenesis</a>. The cutting of fibronectins and vitronectins delays the formation of a provisional matrix impairing wound healing further.
T cell Regulation.
Granzyme B is secreted by <a href="regulatory%20T%20cells">regulatory T cells</a> to kill <a href="CD4">CD4</a>+ T cells that have not been exposed to host cells that are restricted to the peripheral tissues and cannot reach the <a href="thymus">thymus</a>. This <a href="activation-induced%20cell%20death%20%28AICD%29">activation-induced cell death (AICD)</a> can be achieved without the <a href="Fas%20receptor">Fas</a> death pathway and prevents <a href="autoimmunity">autoimmune reaction</a> to <a href="antigen">self antigens</a>.
Inhibitors.
Granzyme B's most common inhibitor is <a href="SERPINB9">SERPINB9</a> also known as proteinase inhibitor nine (PI-9) which is 376 amino acids long and found in the nucleus and cytoplasm.
It is produced by many types of cell to protect themselves from accidental granzyme B mediated cell death. PI-9 is <a href="metastability">metastable</a> and forms an energetically favourable conformation when bound to granzyme B. The reactive loop centre (RCL) of the PI-9 molecule acts as a pseudosubstrate and initially forms a reversible Michaelis complex. Once the <a href="peptide%20bond">peptide bond</a> of the RCL is cleaved between positions P1 and P1', granzyme B is permanently inhibited.
However, if the RCL is cleaved efficiently, PI-9 does not act as a 1:1 <a href="suicide%20inhibition">suicide substrate</a> and granzyme B is left uninhibited. <a href="GZMM">Granzyme M</a> can also cleave PI-9 in the nucleus and cytoplasm to relieve granzyme B of inhibition.
Protein L4-100K from <a href="adenoviridae">adenoviruses</a> can also inhibit granzyme B by binding at <a href="exosite">exosite</a>s and specific binding pockets. L4-100K is an assembly protein that can transport <a href="capsomere">hexon capsomeres</a> into the nucleus of an adenovirus. 100k can be cleaved to a 90kDa fragment by <a href="granzyme%20H">granzyme H</a> to relieve this inhibition which is important in adenovirus 5 infected cells.
Role in Disease.
Granzyme B has a normal concentration of 20-40 pg/ml in the <a href="blood%20plasma">blood plasma</a> while retaining 70% activity and elevated concentrations of granzyme B are found in a number of disease states.
Granzyme B can generate autoantigens by cleaving in disordered regions and linker regions of antigens exposing new <a href="epitopes">epitopes</a> and this can cause the development of autoimmune diseases.
Granzyme B release with perforin from <a href="CD8">CD8+</a> T cells can cause <a href="heart">heart</a> and <a href="kidney">kidney</a> <a href="transplant%20rejection">transplant rejection</a> through killing of allogeneic endothelial cells. The destruction of <a href="insulin">insulin</a> producing <a href="beta%20cell">β cells</a> in <a href="islets%20of%20Langerhans">pancreatic islets</a> is mediated by T cells and granzyme B contributing to Type 1 Diabetes. Granzyme B can also mediate the death of cells after <a href="spinal%20cord%20injury">spinal cord injury</a> and is found at elevated levels in <a href="rheumatoid%20arthritis">rheumatoid arthritis</a>.
<a href="Chronic%20obstructive%20pulmonary%20disease">COPD</a> (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) has been attributed to granzyme B secreted from NK and T cells causing the apoptosis of <a href="respiratory%20epithelium">bronchial epithelial cells</a>. Matrix destabilisation and remodelling by granzyme B is also linked to <a href="asthma">asthma</a> pathogenesis. 
Granzyme B can kill <a href="melanocytes">melanocytes</a> causing the skin condition <a href="vitiligo">vitiligo</a> and granzyme B overexpression is found in <a href="contact%20dermatitis">contact dermatitis</a>, <a href="lichen%20sclerosus">lichen sclerosus</a> and <a href="lichen%20planus">lichen planus</a> cases.
Cytotoxic cells expressing granzyme B have been identified close to <a href="hair%20follicles">hair follicles</a> linking a possible role in hair loss.
The ECM remodelling properties of granzyme B have also implicated its involvement in <a href="ventricular%20remodeling">left ventricular remodelling</a>, which increases the subsequent chances of <a href="myocardial%20infarction">myocardial infarction</a>. The weakening of the <a href="fibrous%20cap">fibrous cap</a> of <a href="atheroma">atheromatous plaques</a> by apoptosis of smooth muscle cells has also been linked to granzyme B.
